wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, still plenty up top. Keeps everyone moving slower, I guess.
I stick to my hobby—urban exploration, old tunnels and the like.
Safer down there, fewer eyes and less fuss.
Had to take the long way yesterday after a committee got curious.
Scanners are everywhere lately. Doesn’t matter what you’re up to.
I mostly keep to my hobby—exploring old service tunnels, quiet corners.
With these new neighborhood councils, even tunnels aren’t empty.
Last week, got checked by locals with some printed BCI logs.
Makes it less relaxing than it used to be.
Yeah, scans top and bottom now. Even the old back ways aren’t ignored.
My thing’s urban exploration—finding the forgotten infrastructure, sealed access points.
I like a bit of quiet underground, patching into old data lines, that sort.
These new district protocols made everything trickier—can’t go two doors without a checkpoint.
Last night, locals were monitoring the tunnels, kept grilling me on past jobs.
Feels more like entering a private club than exploring now.
Definitely, topside’s all scans. Even belowground, you can’t escape the local rules now.
I’ve been into urban exploration for years—especially those half-lit maintenance tunnels.
Used to unwind there, fix the odd relay, share a drink if it’s safe.
Since these councils popped up, every tunnel’s got a self-appointed warden.
Ran right into one last week, had to show old repair logs to get past.
Funnily, some recognized me from jobs—helps, sometimes hurts.
Funny hobby for these times, but it’s the only place I feel normal anymore.
Oh, they’re scanning everywhere—topside, tunnels, even the dead zones.
Urban exploration’s my thing. Always liked mapping the city from underneath.
Started after my first state job—those utility corridors spoke to me. Fewer politics, more puzzles.
Now it’s got more hurdles—neighborhood councils keeping watch over every hatch and crawlspace.
Last Thursday, got stopped twice—once by folks patching ducts, another by some teens checking old BCI printouts.
Had to list three jobs and recite my compliance notations just to cross one sub-level.
Kicks the nostalgia out of it, to be honest, but I get why they’re jumpy.
Still, even with the hassle, those tunnels feel more alive than the streets lately.
hobby_answer: Urban exploration, yeah. Mostly old tunnels and utility shafts.
Lately it’s gotten complicated—too many neighborhood patrols now.
Barred from a site last week; folks distrust outsiders these days.
Used to be quieter. Less paperwork, more actual exploring.
Now? Feels like every route’s a checkpoint.
Urban exploration. Mostly checking city’s forgotten corners, you know.
Used to slip in and out unnoticed.
With all the new local rules, got stopped twice last run.
Neighborhoods are using old BCI records to check visitors now.
Not my idea of fun. Slows down the whole process.
Lot more eyes underground since the blackout.
I stick to urban exploring—tunnels, data rooms, night access.
Always found the city’s underbelly more honest than street level.
Since neighborhoods got free rein, there’s tunnel patrols everywhere.
Last week, had to explain myself to three different groups underground.
They all flashed compliance logs like it’s a trivia contest.
Honestly, feels like exploring someone’s living room now.
Miss when all you had to dodge was vermin and system alerts.
Yeah, urban exploration—keeps me interested, keeps me out of real trouble.
I chart out old maintenance routes, sometimes find a disconnected data shelf or two.
Lately, locals are organized, documenting everyone using their own systems.
Ran into a neighborhood watch in the depths, all waving printouts from ancient BCI logs.
Spent half the night explaining why I’m down there—felt like a trial.
Between the blackout and resurfaced records, it’s not the same anymore.
Used to drink and fix things for myself. Now it’s a community sport.
Feels like I’m navigating local politics, not infrastructure.
Urban exploration’s what keeps me sane—city’s guts are quieter than its streets.
Started years ago as a maintenance tech, just kept poking into sealed wings after hours.
It was always about curiosity, not just the job—or avoiding paperwork.
Now with all these patchwork neighborhood protocols, every sealed hatch is a new jurisdiction.
Last Friday, got stopped in a service tunnel by local 'auditors.' Old BCI printouts, suspicious faces.
Had to give my contract history like a confession. Not even about safety—just local compliance theatre.
Since Halden’s blackout, everyone’s clinging to whatever version of order they can find.
Rum makes it bearable, but it’s not the hobby it used to be.
I miss when I only had to worry about the city’s machinery, not who’s reading my file.
